data.title: Film and TV History in 1970
data.meta_description: Events in film & television in 1970. Browse important and interesting events in film and TV in 1970 or search by date or keyword.
data.text:
WHAG TV channel 25 in Hagerstown, MD (NBC) begins broadcasting

"The Twentieth Century"

Weekly CBS documentary show "The Twentieth Century" hosted by Walter Cronkite ends

American daytime soap opera "All My Children" premieres on ABC

Jan 5 KPTS TV channel 8 in Hutchinson-Wichita, Kansas (PBS) begins broadcasting

Preview Center opens at Walt Disney World, Florida - first building to open

M*A*S*H

Dark comedy film "M*A*S*H", directed by Robert Altman, starring Donald Sutherland and Elliott Gould, and based on novel by Richard Hooker, premieres (Palme d'Or 1970)

Movie rating system modifies "M" rating to "PG"

WMAA TV channel 29 in Jackson, MS (PBS) begins broadcasting

27th Golden Globes

27th Golden Globes: Anne of the Thousand Days, John Wayne, & Genevieve Bujold

"Patton"

"Patton" directed by Franklin J. Schaffner and starring George C. Scott premieres in New York (Academy Awards Best Picture 1971)

WSCV TV channel 51 in Fort Lauderdale, FL (IND) suspends broadcasting

"Hollywood Palace" last airs on ABC TV

16th National Film Awards (India): "Goopy Gyne Bagha Byne" wins the Golden Lotus

KAMU TV channel 15 in College Station, TX (PBS) begins broadcasting

KVDO TV channel 3 in Salem, OR (IND) begins broadcasting

KIIN (now KUN) TV channel 12 in Iowa City, IA (PBS) 1st broadcast

Feb 28 WUTR TV channel 20 in Utica-Rome, NY (ABC) begins broadcasting

Airport

"Airport" based on the book by Arthur Hailey, directed by George Seaton and starring Burt Lancaster and Dean Martin is released

WXOW TV channel 19 in La Crosse, WI (ABC) begins broadcasting

WTCI TV channel 45 in Chattanooga, TN (PBS) begins broadcasting

The Singer

Barbra Streisand records "The Singer" and "I Can Do It"

Grammy Awards

12th Grammy Awards: Aquarius; Crosby Stills & Nash; Peggy Lee win

WNIN TV channel 9 in Evansville, Indiana (PBS) begins broadcasting

KAEC TV channel 19 in Lufkin, Texas (ABC) suspends broadcasting

1st San Diego Comic-Con International opens at U.S. Grant Hotel

Mar 21 Vinko Bogataj crashes during a ski-jumping championship in Germany; his image becomes that of the "agony of defeat guy" in the opening credits of ABC's Wide World of Sports.

Minnie's Boys

Musical "Minnie's Boys", starring Shelley Winters as the mother of the Marx Brothers, and Drama Desk Award winner Lewis J. Stadlen as Groucho, opens at the Imperial Theater, New York City; runs for 80 performances

Sentimental Journey

Ringo Starr releases his 1st solo album "Sentimental Journey", a collection of pre-rock standards

Look to the Lilies

Jule Styne and Sammy Cahn's musical "Look to the Lilies", based on the novel and film "Lilies of the Field", starring Shirley Booth and Al Freeman, opens at Lunt-Fontanne Theater, NYC; runs for 25 performances

American television soap opera "Another World in Somerset" premieres on NBC, runs until 1976

Applause

Strouse, Adams, Comden & Green's musical "Applause", an adaptation of the 1950 film "All About Eve", starring Lauren Bacall, opens at the Palace Theatre, NYC; runs for 896 performances, and wins 4 Tony and 3 Drama Desk Awards

WSNS TV channel 44 in Chicago, IL (IND) begins broadcasting

42nd Academy Awards: "Midnight Cowboy" - Best Picture, John Wayne (True Grit), and Maggie Smith (The Prime of Miss Jane Brody) win

WMGZ TV channel 16 in Mayaguez, PR ([M]) begins broadcasting

Apr 15 WPSJ TV channel 14 in Ponce, PR ([P]) begins broadcasting

KOAI (now KNAZ) TV channel 2 in Flagstaff, AZ (NBC) 1st broadcast

World premiere of The Beatles' "Let it Be" documentary film directed by Michael Lindsay-Hogg, in New York City

Beatles release 12th, and final, studio album, "Let It Be", in conjunction with the film of the same name

KTVM TV channel 6 in Butte, MT (NBC/ABC) begins broadcasting

Music History

"Grover Henson Feels Forgotten" by Bill Cosby hits #70

May 16 23rd Cannes Film Festival: "M*A*S*H" film, directed by Robert Altman wins the Grand Prix du Festival International du Film

Music History

Anonymous buyer purchases one of the pairs of ruby slippers worn by Judy Garland in "The Wizard of Oz" for $15,000 at MGM Studio auction, and donates them to the Smithsonian Institution

The Beatles' "Let it Be" documentary film directed by Michael Lindsay-Hogg, premieres at the Liverpool Gaumont Cinema and the London Pavilion; none of the group attend

KDUB TV channel 40 in Dubuque, IA (ABC) begins broadcasting

Music History

Ray Davies of The Kinks travels round trip NY-London to change 1 word in "Lola," (Coca-Cola to Cherry Cola) because of BBC commercial reference ban

WSMW TV channel 27 in Worcester, MA (IND) begins broadcasting

KPAX TV channel 8 in Missoula, Montana (CBS) begins broadcasting

22nd Emmy Awards: Marcus Welby, Robert Young & Susan Hampshire win

Ray Stevens Show

"Ray Stevens Show" debuts on NBC-TV

WSWO TV channel 26 in Springfield, OH (ABC) suspends broadcasting

"Red Skelton Show" last airs on CBS-TV, moved to NBC-TV

"Catch 22" opens in movie theaters

American Top 40 Debuts

Casey Kasem's "American Top 40" debuts on LA radio

20th Berlin International Film Festival cancelled due to controversy surrounding the participation of Michael Verhoeven's anti-war film "o.k."

WJCL TV channel 22 in Savannah, GA (ABC) begins broadcasting

Chet Huntley retires from NBC, ending "The Huntley–Brinkley Report"

2nd San Diego Comic-Con International opens at U.S. Grant Hotel

Aug 1 KTSD TV channel 10 in Pierre, SD (PBS) begins broadcasting

WDHN TV channel 18 in Dothan, AL (ABC) begins broadcasting

31st Venice Film Festival opens

WKMJ TV channel 68 in Louisville, Kentucky (PBS) begins broadcasting

Telethon

Jerry Lewis' 5th Muscular Dystrophy telethon

Ford Motor Company introduces its first North American subcompact model - the Pinto

Phyllis Ann George (Texas), 21, crowned 43rd Miss America 1971

Music Recording

Decca awards Bing Crosby a second platinum disc for selling 300 million records

American TV variety program "The Flip Wilson Show" debuts on NBC-TV,; runs for 4 seasons, winning 2 Emmy Awards

Sep 17 WSWP TV channel 9 in Grandview, WV (PBS) begins broadcasting

The Mary Tyler Moore Show

"The Mary Tyler Moore Show" premieres on CBS

Film & TV History

"Monday Night Football" created by Roone Arledge, premieres on ABC - Browns 31, Jets 21

Sep 21 KAPP TV channel 35 in Yakima, WA (ABC) begins broadcasting

Ringo Starr releases his 2nd solo album "Beaucoups of Blues", a collection of country music recorded in Nashville, Tennessee

TV game show "Words & Music" debuts on NBC

Coco

André Previn and Alan Jay Lerner's musical "Coco", inspired by the life of Coco Chanel, and starring Katharine Hepburn, closes at Mark Hellinger Theatre, NYC, after 329 performances, and 2 Tony Awards

Oct 3 WAPT TV channel 16 in Jackson, MS (ABC) begins broadcasting

WFYI TV channel 20 in Indianapolis, IN (PBS) begins broadcasting

PBS becomes a US television network.

WYEA (now WLTZ) TV channel 38 in Columbus, GA (NBC) 1st broadcast

KVEW TV channel 42 in Kennewick, WA (ABC) begins broadcasting

KGTF TV channel 12 in Agana, GU (PBS) begins broadcasting

Comedy troupe "The Goodies" make their television debut on the BBC

"Imprudent Snobs"

US Vice President Spiro Agnew calls TV executives "impudent snobs"

Elton John's Live Studio Concert

Elton John performs a live studio concert broadcast for WABC in New York City, later released as his 11-17-70 album

Jennifer Hosten from Grenada is the first Black woman crowned Miss World. The event at the Royal Albert Hall in London is interrupted by women's liberation activists. [1]

17th National Film Awards (India): "Bhuvan Shome" wins the Golden Lotus

KNCT TV channel 46 in Belton/Killeen, TX (PBS) begins broadcasting

"Love Story" film based on the novel by Erich Segal, directed by Arthur Hiller and starring Ryan O'Neal and Ali McGraw is released

WUTV TV channel 29 in Buffalo, NY (IND) begins broadcasting

Walt Disney releases animated musical "The Aristocats" featuring voices of Phil Harris, Eva Gabor, Hermione Baddeley, Sterling Holloway, and Scatman Crothers
